title: Synthetic Recap
body:
In a performance for the ages, Patrick Ewing authored a masterpiece of pure dominance, single-handedly dismantling the Toronto Raptors as his New York Knicks cruised to a 93-70 victory in 1998. The final score was merely a formality; the real story was the historic, 44-point eruption from the Knicks’ legendary center.

From the opening tip, Ewing was an unstoppable force. The Raptors had no answer for his methodical, powerful low-post game. He operated with a devastating efficiency, hitting mid-range jumpers, finishing through contact, and controlling the paint with an authority that left the opposition reeling. Each basket was a systematic deconstruction of the defense, a testament to his complete offensive arsenal. His 44 points weren't just high; they were a monumental achievement, accounting for nearly half of his team's entire offensive output.

While Allan Houston provided valuable support with 14 points, and Larry Johnson anchored the boards with 11 rebounds, this night belonged solely to Ewing. His gargantuan effort on the offensive end was matched by a relentless defensive presence, contributing to a staggering 12 blocks for the Knicks as a team. This defensive wall suffocated the Raptors, holding them to a paltry 70 points.

The game was less a contest and more a coronation of one of the game's greats at his absolute peak. On this night, Patrick Ewing didn't just play basketball; he transcended it, delivering a legendary performance that reminded everyone of his Hall of Fame pedigree and cementing this evening as one of the most dominant individual showcases of the era.
